intro: Siphocampylus virgatus var. atrichus, commonly known as the black-hairy beardtongue, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, dark green leaves and showy, tubular flowers that range from purple to pink. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly habitats, preferring full sun to partial shade. Its unique morphology and habitat preferences make it an interesting subject for botanical study and conservation efforts.
